title: Biodegradable straw but in a plastic cup - why!? - Reddit
body: A) Specifically plastic straws came in for public awareness and opposition because of a famous video where some marine biologists caught a sea turtle who had a plastic straw lodged in his nostril, apparently for years, and it had to be very painfully extracted from the turtle's face with pliers. Like the famous photos from decades ago of the ...
readable_content:
rewardiflost (2023-12-08): Is the cup reusable or recyclable? Straws traditionally are not recyclable due to size/shape as well as material.

Plus, there aren't any depressing photos of turtles with entire cups stuck up their nose. Straws? Sure. Not cups though.

summary:
The conversation seems to be focused on the recyclability of cups and straws, as well as the enforcement of rules within the subreddit. There's a reference to the absence of distressing images related to cups compared to straws, suggesting a call for attention to the environmental impact of both products. Overall, the sentiment seems to lean towards a serious discussion about sustainability and rules, with a slight touch of humor about the lack of attention given to cups in comparison to straws.

Sentiment: 0.6
